HnhFEdTpeGfiJKJSZ0-4uw.text: Looking for something to do late on a weeknight? Late night specials 10-12!! It was a Tuesday night and I saw this restaurant pop up and always wanted to try, so my husband and I went in at 10pm. There was only one other person sitting at the bar, but given time, the whole bar was filled.   Our bartender/server was very attentive. She gave food recommendations on their late night menu and so we tried a couple items. Out of our sampling, I'd recommend these 3:  Ham & Cheese Croquettes- 4.5/5 cheesy, crumbly/crusty melt in your mouth. There were 3 small ones per serving with a garlic aioli sauce. Steak(Arrachera) Taco- 4.8/5 steak was cooked perfectly, there was crumbly blue cheese inside a corn tortilla with a few jalapenos for a kick. Mahi Mahi Taco- 4.9/5 plantain crusted so very crispy and sweet which balanced out the fish, chipotle mayo, and cabbage. Wonderful flavor balance.  The drinks were good, but I enjoyed the food the most. The decorations inside are also fantastic, like being on a boat. There was a wood ceiling over the bar, seascape murals on the wall, a quartz-like bar top, and comfy velvet chairs. Portions are pretty small on the late night menu, so you'd have to order a few if you're starving but overall great experience and it's nice seeing new & different restaurants pop up downtown.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. One of the many murals
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bar/late night menu

BjrHk4BiB3o7JhkexmZTnQ.text: First off, the servers and staff were great. Very friendly and quick.    From the outside the place looked closed. It was dark inside and very few restaurants are open downtown on Sundays, so I almost walked past.  Once inside the decor was great.  The rum selection was very impressive and I started with their version of an old fashioned.  It was great and the banana and walnut flavor wasn't overly powerful.  On the menu, The East Indian crab cakes caught my eye so that's what I ordered.  They were plated nicely and the the portion was huge.  It came with greens on top and a mango salsa.  The greens were okay, loads of steams.  The mango salsa was outstanding. Probably the best fruit based salsa I've ever had.  The crab cakes were very mushy and the star of the show wasn't present.  While I could see the crab, I couldn't taste it. Hopefully I'm wrong but it tasted like canned crab. Which is not worth $28 price tag.  It wasn't the worst crab cake I've ever had, but its no were near the best.  Very middle of the road.  Overall I really liked the place and I do plan on returning. Hopefully the crab cakes were a dud and the next dish will blow me away.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. East Indian Crab Cakes.

HRbvxUyUaqXX-KFPhZqdxA.text: I came to Pirata for the first time during lunch yesterday. The interior was everything I expected it to be and really made you feel like you were off on an island somewhere. Ron Molinaro, who owns Il Pizzaiolo and Pizzuvio, also owns Pirata. I love both Il Pizzaiolo and Pizzuvio so I couldn't wait to give Pirata a try.   The first thing that I was drawn to was the smoked pineapple guacamole for an appetizer. I love plantain chips and love pineapple and guacamole, but the $12 price for an appetizer seemed a bit much. I was set on getting the smoked jackfruit tacos, until I was told they didn't have that anymore. They also didn't have the Jamaican curried goat tacos. There is nothing more disappointing than being told the menu item you want cannot be made. My second option was the skirt steak tacos($15). The tacos are topped with garlic mojo, arugula, watermelon radish sofritto, and salsa de arbol. You get two tacos which I thought were generously layered with tiny bits of steak. The steak was seasoned and cooked to perfection. The garlic mojo has a bit of a kick to it, but pairing it with the watermelon radish sofritto brought a nice mix of sweet and spicy. My friend ordered the burger and fries and really raved about it. I did try some of her fries and they were the perfect tiny crunchy kind. I would like to come back to Pirata and give their empanadas a try!

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Skirt Steak Taco

NyH1IQjBMa-8SApqzcGuag.text: Amazing first experience at Pirata! I stopped in for a quick lunch and I was not disappointed with a single thing we ordered off the menu. We started with the malangas fritters for our appetizer - so delicious! You get four fried malanga balls that are paired with a garlic aioli dipping sauce. Deep fried then covered in more fat - nothing sounds more delicious yet fatal than that. For my entree, I went with the kale & arugula salad which comes in a very good portion size. The burnt honey vinaigrette was delicious yet light. It is topped with pickled watermelon (a little weird), pumpkin seeds, and goat cheese. My only complaint would be the pumpkin seeds which were way too tough to even bite. I had to hand pick them out of my salad before I choked on one of them. We also ordered the papas fritas and sweet plantains for sides. They also come in very generous portion sizes. The fries came with Jamaican ketchup which, dare I say, I actually liked more than the regular ketchup (I'm sorry all you Heinz lovers). For the end of the meal, the sweet plantains served as a nice (healthy-ish) dessert alternative.  Service was good throughout the entire meal. Everyone was very friendly and since the restaurant was slow during our visit, service was prompt and all our food came out quickly. Highly recommend Pirata for anyone looking to test out some unique cuisine downtown!

tMyTWvconsljDNhO-Slphw.text: I came here last year and it was good - this time, it was amazing. I got Arroz con Pollo, Patatas Rellanos, and an amazing mixed drink - a Dirty Banana.   The service was also much improved this time. I highly recommend this place!

dOvAfdkqYYRZFIN2eKPtOA.text: So good!!! I had the vegan jerk jackfruit taco on corn tortillas (gluten free). Best vegan meal I've had in years!!! The guacamole was good too!!

d7alqvPTpnUAV2IITIezbA.text: We are visiting from California. Food, drinks, service all 5 stars! Chef Josh was amazing with his costumer service skills and his ability to execute this cuisine to perfection. We had Cuban sandwich and the Arozo con Pollo and the Cuban food is better here than any restaurant I've tried in Miami and California! A must try if you are this area! Great experience.

1sXU2bQtKpRcT6JQz1MWXg.text: I was thrilled to get out of the cold while visiting the holiday market. I was greeted very warmly and given a choice to sit wherever I wanted.  Pirata is a Caribbean themed restaurant and bar. I inquired about their fish offerings and the fish sandwich I was hoping for they were out of. My waiter did suggest that if I wasn't overly hungry that I could opt for their fish tacos. He said they come two to a plate and are very small. They also offer salads and soups. Sides are extra unless you order a sandwich platter.  I decided to go with the fried chicken breast sandwich with fries and Caribbean slaw. He told me that the normally put the coleslaw on the sandwich but at my request they would put it on the side.  The place was fairly empty so I got my food in record time. The chicken was juicy and tender and of course was bigger than the bun. The slaw was also very good. The fries are of the shoestring variety. It is served with a cup of ketchup. I couldn't figure out why each time I ate some of the fries they were hot and peppery. Later I learned it was the Caribbean ketchup they serve which adds a lot of pepper to make it. This was the only thing my waiter forgot to tell me. So heads up. It was fairly dark where I was sitting and easy to mistake it for regular ketchup.  Yes, you can ask for regular ketchup. This restaurant and bar is a welcome addition to our city and is located a little more than a block past Market Square. I was very intrigued with the mural they had on the wall and the manager said she will contact the painter in Florida and send me a picture of the full mural. Looking forward to returning here on a future visit downtown.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fried chicken with fries and Caribbean slaw
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bar area
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Other side of picture

_VvbDYdPuzZoZG0ix2EaGg.text: Such good food and a fun atmosphere! Walked in here on a Saturday night with out of town visitors (had tried initially to go somewhere else, but there was a crazy wait) - and frankly this ended up being significantly better than my original plan.   I ordered vegetarian empanadas and a vegetarian curry - both were amazing.  You get one empanada in an order and it was a great appetizer.  The curry was very generous and delicious!  If you like hot sauce (that has a kick), make sure to get the mango habanero sauce - a little bit goes a long way.   I'm definitely putting this on the list of places to revisit. The service was great and like I said - the atmosphere was a lot of fun!

Nb4o1kFGFbuVycgDYcSMJg.text: We tried Pirata for the first time tonight. I would have like to give it 4 1/2 stars, but I can't figure out how to do that:) Our waiter Alex was very nice, personable & honest in his recommendations ("not necessary to get a protein on the the fruit salad").  This is not a "hoidy-toidy " place--just fresh, Caribbean-Inspired dishes.  We had the Guac Trio, with fresh Plantain chips---awesome! My dining partner and I had the Grouper Taco and the Ropa  V Taco -both wonderful. We split the Tres Leches dessert which was very good. Not too sweet.  They have a short wine list, but decent. I had a House Red-fine.  They have an impressive rum & tequila menu, though we did not sample it. We did though have a Slane Whiskey sip--try it! I'm not a whiskey person, but it's excessively smooth. We had it out of curiosity, having an unopened bottle at home from vacation that included Slane Castle & distillery in Ireland. In short, try this place--good food at a fair price & friendly people--clean restrooms!

eTw-RN4IN4VZlL7o7JIBfQ.text: We dropped in after work on Friday night to grab a small bite and have a drink before heading over to the Holiday Marketplace in Market Square.  We stumbled on Pirata and decided to walk their plank.  I'll try not to work in too many pirate references but it will be hard.    The scurvy dog serving up tasty cocktails was not real friendly but I think they were pretty slammed before we arrived so maybe he was just worn out or perhaps incurred a serious keel hauling earlier.  The drinks he made for us were really delicious.  I tried the Man O War which is straight rum with some other booze over a huge ice cube so it's stronnnnnng like Cap'n Black's breath after three months at sea. Argh!  My mate tried Meg's Peg Leg which was vodka, cuke flavoring, sage and thai spices which left her adrift.    We tried the pollo (that's chicken for ye English landlubbers) fricassee empanada with a spicy red sauce on the side that was quite delicious and the lechon pork and corn tacos which were not as successful.  In both tacos, there was a very large (bigger than a grape) hunk of pure pork fat.  It was really not good.  The pork itself was very bland and the corn and other taco toppings were no help in the taste department.  I pointed out the huge hunks of fat to the bartender when he stopped by to collect our plates and he just shrugged and said, "oh."  No apologies.  No questions.  It was a little off-putting as far as responses go when you bring something to a restaurant's attention.   They have only been open five weeks so let's hope their Quartermaster picks up their game in the food department.  Their drinks can float my armada any day.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Peg Leg Meg &amp; Man O War cocktails

2G71o4NV6gKdOCPxsBdrFA.text: After watching a show at the Benedum my wife and I were hungry and needed to find a place to eat.  We had some restaurants in mind but my wife found this place on Yelp and we decided to try it out.  She said it was a newer restaurant but we didn't know how new it was until we got here.  We knew Pirata was located in Market Square but it took us a few minutes to finally find it.  Luckily we had our treasure map!  (That was a joke for the comedy).  Anyways we walk in and it's not too busy but the restaurant looks great.  It was an unusually warm fall day in the Burgh so they had it all opened up in the restaurant.  You could tell it was new and it looked nice and modern.  So we walked right up to the bar.  The bar was a good size and you could see the televisions really well too.  It's a good set up.  The bartender greeted us and we dove into the food and drink menu.  We were hungry so we knew we wanted some kind of appetizer before our main dish.  The empanadas intrigued us.  They had three to choose from.  The Jamaican beef patty, pollo pricasse, and the beef picadillo.  We ordered the Jamaican beef and the Pollo one.  They were $3 each and we both shared them.  They were good and the salsa type dish that came with it was good to dip in.  We probably would have liked it spicier but it was still good.  I preferred the pollo the most.  I could have eaten a few more of those!  Looking around you can tell that this was a new restaurant.  They were having a little trouble with their background music and getting it right.  The bartender wasn't too sure about some things on the menu.  The owner/GM/Manager was all around making sure things were good.  It just felt like they haven't been doing this for too long.  Nothing bad about that but you could just tell.  We decided to order their fish tacos.  My wife didn't want the fish fried so she asked the bartender if they could grill them.  The bartender didn't know if they could but she was nice about it and said that she would ask the kitchen.  She came back and said that they could grill the fish for her fish tacos.  I decided to do the same thing.    I didn't mention this before but when our empanadas came out our fish tacos came out at the same time.  I really don't like when the appetizer and your main dish come out together.  The head guy there that was walking around walked past us and asked us if we had asked for the fish to be grilled. We said yes because we couldn't tell by looking at it if it was fried or not.  He said it was fried and he will get us new tacos.  I was fine with that because it gave us a little more time to enjoy our appetizer.  He was really nice about it too.  He didn't let us find out for ourselves.  He was proactive and that's what made a big difference this night.  He came back about 5 minutes later with no tacos.  He apologized and said that they will take care of the tacos for us because they are being delayed.  What had happened is they grilled the fish but it wasn't to the satisfactory of the boss so he sent it back.  I love that!  They knew that we were waiting for our order so they probably rushed it and it wasn't right.  A lot of places would have just sent it to us and had us send it back and we would be very unsatisfied.  Again he was proactive and took matters into his own hands.  Great job my man!  It sort of reminds me of Gordon Ramsay's kitchen on TV.  He probably smashed that fish with his fist when it came out poorly!  A few minutes later the fish finally came out and it looked really good.  I started eating my fish and it tasted great.  My wife bit into her fish and it was actually cold in the middle.  It was a little raw which was disappointing.  She sent it back and they started another order for her.  We shared my tacos so she didn't have to wait.  Then about 5 minutes later her tacos came out again and they were cooked all of the way through this time.  We ate those together and they tasted really good as well.  Since we weren't paying for them we weren't upset.  They were upfront that they were new and working out some kinks.  We found out that they had only been open for 2 weekends.  So we understand what was happening here and they gave us great service.  This is going to be a very good new restaurant in Market Square.  The atmosphere was really nice, the food was really good, and the staff made no excuses for their mistakes other than they were new.  They admitted to them and made up for it.  We will be back to give them another chance here at Pirata!

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Grilled Fish Tacos
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

Q0dnDyedITRugTnw_rWDQg.text: I came to Pirata with some friends for dinner a few weeks ago! I've been here for drinks before, but this  time, we tried dinner here. I started with the Colombian chicken soup. It was pretty good, but not super flavorful. I also ordered the Jamaican beef patty and a puerro (leek) and queso fritto empanada. My other friends also ordered the Jamaican beef patty with some other items. For all of us, the beef patty was the star of the show. The crust was flaky and the filling was delicious! I gave Pirata three stars for a couple reasons. First, nothing that I tried (my own order or things that my friends ordered) truly blew me out of the water. Also, our waitress was really nice, but kind of pushy. She came around constantly and removed plates from our table, that she thought we were finished with. There were a few times where we had a few more bites of food on the plate and she just removed them without asking if we were finished first. I got the feeling you get when a place is about to close and the employees are trying to quickly clean up... only we had about three hours before the place was closing for the night. I think next time, I will stick to the drinks at Pirata.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Colombian chicken soup
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Jamaican beef patty &amp; puerro and queso fritto empanada

rYA6Y0L3_ebREaDuemKLNA.text: I hate to be the first one to give this place a not so great review but it has to be done. I've been passing this place for a few months now waiting and waiting for it to open. As soon as I found out it was I made plans to go the next chance I had. Sadly it didn't live up to my excitement.   The restaurant itself has its niche down. All of the decor fits together perfectly and it's beautiful. The prices and the food on the other hand, not so great. My friend and I ordered one of each of the 3 empanadas to share. The chicken one was by far the best. The beef patty had a weird taste that neither of us really cared for. The other beef one was ok but nothing impressive. All of them were paired with what tasted like a roasted tomato salsa. I have to say it was relatively tasteless.   As my entree I got the Lechon tacos which are pork tacos topped with some peppers and corn. Sadly they weren't that great either. They were missing something that would give them more flavor. What I really didn't care for was the fact my tacos were dripping oil all over my plate and hands. They should probably use a little less going forward. I also ordered a side of their spicy macaroni pie (macaroni and cheese). I thought it was ok but my friend did not care for it because it tasted like it had nutmeg in it.  We ordered a few drinks as part of our meal as well. The Jenny's tea cup and the dirty banana were both delicious. I would highly recommend. My only real problem is the price of the drinks. Or the price of everything rather. If I'm going to pay quite a bit for a meal it should be because it's large portions or because it's phenomenal food. Neither of which are True for pirata. I wasn't overly impressed with anything and I left with no leftovers. Which is saying a lot for me because I don't eat a lot. Overall I think the experience was just ok.

zAGV69pMAvIxCpdpWfjlUA.text: Stopped into the restaurants randomly at 4 in a Saturday and was pleasantly surprised.  We sat at the bar.  Great bartenders and recommendations.  We had the peg leg meg, mojito, Antigua tea and the walking dead to drink. All were great drinks and strong!   To eat we tried 2 of the 3 empanadas choices: Jamaican patty and  picadillo steak.  Both were delish and flavorful and i want more of them now.  We also got the wings, Jamaican corn and Mac n cheese.  All were great, Mac n cheese was probably the star of the three.  The corn was different and tasty.  The wings were good, by nothing special.  I did really like the herby dip that went with them.   The vibe was cool, the bartenders were great and loved the Caribbean music.  I will definitely be back!

NbTHTNelG0CFRK8HM1idAw.text: Amazing location, amazing atmosphere, great rum and great food. Matt was my bartender and he was awesome did a hell of a job. The beef empanada was amazing with the homemade hot sauce and I got the arroz con pollo as a meal and it was amazing! Definitely check this place out. Get ya an empanada.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

RH-U8vAowShf-FjZycwT-g.text: Came here on recommendation of a friend. It feels cool to be checking out a place when it's still new. It's in a bit of a rundown/creepy area of downtown but the interior is really nice. Made me feel like I was on a Caribbean cruise except more sophisticated.   Our waiter was nice and pretty attentive. It was empty-ish for a Friday night (albeit it was 7pm and sooo cold that night). I really appreciated the easy online reservations and the text reminders. The ability to text if I was running late was another really great added bonus.  We got the Jamaican beef patties - they were delicious. Lots of cumin flavor which reminds me of Indian food. In fact, the menu has a lot of Indian influences like rotis and chutneys.   We shared the Cubano sandwich and a side of rice and beans. Of note, you can't sub out the fries on the Cubano which is a bummer. The rice was delicious though :)

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

DOo6X5yQ_aVC3n7vb8Tnqg.text: The place is neat and clean, the servers are friendly and attentive, and you feel welcome from the moment the elegant hostess meets you, to the exhaustive and informed explanation by your waitress (serving personnel is almost exclusively women, but that's neither here nor there). The menu is relatively short, but oh so hard to pick from. The appetizers are a wonderful selection (varying from pineapple guac to simple fried plantains to delicious looking fritters), matched by the simple but tasty empanadas.  We skipped the sandwiches and focused on the tacos, each of which was very original (including our choices, open blue mai mai and the pork one), and they even have a weekly special one, and we rounded them off with a spicy Mac and cheese which was a well balanced fusion of American and Jamaican. Our friends ventured into the entree section and were rewarded by a crunchy, zesty jerky chicken, served with rice and beans and plantains. The dish was large and the chicken perfectly tender. I'm usually not a fan of rum, but the passion fruit concoction my wife got was heaven in a glass. I can't vouch for their signature Dirty Banana, since I loath coffee, but the others, who tried it, testify on its behalf. The only two issues were the music (general summer hits played a tad too loud) and the price (good for the value but not cheap on a simple scale). Would definitely go back.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

I5BNNF8Bn0hnIZz-bgLQZA.text: I sincerely enjoyed the full experience of dining here, from the tasty food to the exciting mural and decor. I'm the exact type of person Pirata caters to: I love spicy food, I love rum, and I love PIRATES (True Story- I have 3 pirate costumes at home right now). Quite possibly, I've been waiting for a pirate-themed restaurant my entire life.  I went with a friend. We decided to share everything so we could get the full flavor spectrum at Pirata. We started with drinks. She got the Jenny's Tea Cup, I got the Dirty Banana. The Dirty Banana was delicious, like a milkshake that has a dark past. The Tea Cup was too sweet for me...  I was going to order the Jerk Chicken, but my friend beat me to it. I ordered their take on the Cuban sandwich. We both decided we liked the other's dish better! The Jerk Chicken and accompaniment of rice was a tad too spicy for her, but I thought that dish was A+. I liked the Cuban sandwich too, but it was more or less a run-of-the-mill Cuban... I would love it if it had a bit more pizzazz. Maybe a different type of sauce? The mustard on it didn't do it justice.  The waitress was nice, although she did make herself scarce.  My only real complaint... Well, it could use more pirate decorations!

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Empanadas and Greens
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Island Spice, a green juice based margarita with old bay on the rim... Interesting!
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Jerk Chicken

C_EHARf8SVAKVpafnEqjJw.text: Cool, fun place to have different, delicious food!  They have a huge drink menu with tons of rum so had to get a rum drink. Hubby got the mojito (a little sweet) and I had some kind of cucumber spicy margarita (a little too green).  Both were pricey at $12 a piece - next time I'll probably go for a rum flight.    The food was so reasonably priced and so good! We got a bunch of little plates so we could try a bit of everything which was perfect.  Chicken adobo wings (awesome smokey with a great light creamy dipping sauce), papas bravas - crispy potatoes - wasn't expecting the spicy sauce all over them but was still good.  Ordered all 3 kinds of the empanadas which were tasty and so cheap ($2 bucks apiece). And also got the beans and rice (very flavorful).   They also give you your choice of flat or fizzy water for free!   It was Friday night.and they had a dj that came in around 11 playing super fun music - will totally be back.    The only bummer was the waitress, who was super nice and friendly, took forever to stop back so we could get our check to leave - other than that it was great.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Adobo chicken wings - yum!
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Papas bravas - Crispy potatoes with a spicy sauce -pretty good
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Empanadas - YUM!

oMkfgTxXDbn8pj0a19KdAA.text: I was here for a friend's birthday party. It was on a Thursday evening and there was no wait time. Service was good. The person who waited on us was very patient and friendly.  We ordered a variety of items ranging from appetizers to dessert. We were group of 6 people. We ordered a pitcher of sangria, 2 plates of yuca frita, 1 regular chips, 1 jerk chicken taco, 4 chicken empanadas, 1 adobo chicken wings with dry jerk seasoning. Yuca frita are taro root chips served with a ranch flavored dipping sauce. They also have pineapple salsa and mango salsa on the table that you can use as a dip for yuca frita. The fritas are not oily yet they were crispy to some extent. We all liked it.  Regular chips are typical french fries that you find at any other restaurant. My favorite is the adobo chicken wings with dry jerk seasoning. My first bite was salty, but I liked the taste after the second bite once my palette got used to the flavor. I will order these crispy well cooked wings again when I go there next time. We all liked the chicken empanadas, specially with the tamarind dipping on the side. It is sour and sweet flavored with a bright red color and rough texture. Chicken empanadas are well cooked with a crispy outer layer. Final item in the appetizers is the jerk chicken taco that was well seasoned.   For entree, we ordered three dishes: house special lamb which tasted like a well braised lamb with some curry flavor served over a bed a rice, fried sweet plantains, and a wedge of lime. A drizzle of lime on the tender goat meat hits the ball out of the park. Along with that, we ordered house special Salmon which is panseared and served over sweet potato puree, edible flower and guava flavored sauce on the side. I didn't taste the guava flavored sauce since salmon is well cooked and delicious with a crispy outer skin. The sweet potato puree is the best with subtle flavor.   The only disappointment was the third entree they served which is traiditional Spanish dish (chicken paella) that was mushy and seemed over cooked. We asked them for clarification about the dish quality and they were totally cool about it. Infact, they acknowledged that it is not supposed to be overcooked and deducted the amount from our final bill. This is a nice gesture.   Finally for dessert, we ordered tres leches which is delicious and ended the dinner on a great note. It is soft cake that is served with some milk and has an amazing taste.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken empanada served with delicious tamarind sauce that goes well with the empanada.
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Regular chips yet delicious...
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken wings seasoned with dry jerk spice!

RRcwIaON-SjpfBg6IjAtNg.text: Love, love, love the music! So happy to have a place where I hear so many of my favorite Spanish songs, and have an awesome selection of rums and cocktails to choose from. This is my type of bar.  I'd been wanting to try Pirata for a while and finally had a chance to duck in for a drink. The bartender, Carlo, was friendly, answered my questions about the cocktails and offered to make me something else when I asked about other drinks with cardamom. The concoction he came up with was really good! It was fun watching the bartenders make the drinks and the food looked good too. The bar was a nice clean, open area and there's actually a big dining area in the back too. Can't wait to come back to try the food and more drinks.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Cocktail menu
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bartender&#39;s cardamom rum concoction - just the right balance of flavors!

ScNILvF6YdglvBXBrIHOZA.text: This is one of the best restaurants in Pittsburgh. Everything on the menu is absolutely delicious and the drinks are fantastic. I definitely recommend trying their house hot sauces-they are spicy but so good! When we went, we ordered a bunch of small plates and shared...that was the way to go because then we could try it all! They are vegetarian friendly too, which was a bonus (try the bbq jackfruit tacos...AMAZING)! Some of the drinks have nuts, so if you have allergies like me, be aware of this. Overall, this is a must try place! I'll definitely be going back!

9RgmKd8GI_DGh06xhKmSDg.text: I came here for a few drinks while in town over the holidays with my husband.  We bellied up to the bar and ordered a bottle of overpriced wine for $45.  When our bill came, they tried to charge us $110 for it even though there isn't a single drink or bottle on the menu that costs that much!  The music was also SO loud my glass was shaking on the bar.  One and done here.

QCjntktBpfnnYfcNyLoseQ.text: Not only an impressive selection of rums from around the regions of the world the produce rum, but also incredibly knowledgeable staff!  I had a delightful happy hour here speaking with bar manager Elena who educated me on the various regions and style of rum distilling. One new fave was a Jamaican rum from distiller Smith & Cross... navy strength. Yes sir!!!  Bartender Matt kept me supplied with delicious happy hour food and specials and introduced me to a rather delicious Venezuelan rum.  I sampled happy hour sized smoky pineapple guacamole with plantain chips - WOW seriously one of the best guacs I've ever had. And I've lived in San Diego and New Mexico which is the bar for me for access to great fresh guacamole. Totally unexpected find in Pittsburgh.  Another awesome aspect of Pirata is the pirate-themed movies that play on the TV with captions and the volume down so you can enjoy conversation but have a good laugh watching Goonies or Pirates of the Caribbean.  Total fan!!! Will return for sure because now I know of a rum based bar and restaurant that delivers on rum and rations.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Jamaica man... naval grade rum yo ho ho!
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Another page...there are more but thats enough for now
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Just one page of the rum offerings

-MtK0AocsjgBRwEZoirZaA.text: We really don't have a plethora of upscale Caribbean restaurants in Pittsburgh.  Most of the local Caribbean restaurants are small neighborhood joints that may be long on flavor but short on decor.  The folks behind Pirata obviously spent some loot on the decor of this restaurant and didn't go kitschy either.(Which would have been very easy to do.)  Additionally, their version of Caribbean isn't tied to one particular country's cuisine.  They have empanadas, as well as conch fritters and adobo chicken wings.  I must also say that the service was extremely welcoming and polite.  The manager on duty seemed to be genuinely interested in feedback on the menu, service, decor, etc.. which was much appreciated.   I met my frequent lunch buddies at the restaurant and on my first visit there, me and one of my lunch buddies ordered the Fried Snapper Sandwich.  My other lunch buddy ordered the Cubano sandwich.  Both sandwiches were served with fries and restaurant-made ketchup. (The ketchup was a very nice touch and different enough to make me notice the difference between their ketchup and our locally produced one.)  The snapper sandwich had a good clean flavor and was accompanied by a Caribbean coleslaw.  Yummy!  And I had to try my buddy's Cubano sandwich, which was also tasty.  My only complaint was that the snapper sandwich was served on an average sesame seed bun.  With so much care given to the menu and fresh ingredients, the bun wasn't worthy of the snapper.  Other than that one complaint, this restaurant deserves to go into my rotation of favorite lunch spots.  I have to try the empanadas the next time I go back to see how theirs stands up next to mine. (I make some mean empanadas!)

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Yeah, mon!

n4s4bsdg59g_Zgq6JlAqVA.text: Great food and drinks. Awesome selection of rums that you don't realize exist. Great bar area with large tvs that are generally playing island or pirate themed movies. Often has dj's on the weekends. Love the peg leg meg drink!

Cr3DXE3pH2cmPBf9hDuHKg.text: We were in town for a wedding and went to Pirata at an off hour -- mid-afternoon for a very late lunch.  Service was fantastic and we ate some of the best food I've had in quite a while.  I'm Gluten Free so we had the Jerk Chicken tacos with tostones underneath.  AMAZING!!!! And then the tuna tartare tacos.  AMAZING!!!! Wait staff was great and my wife had a great drink to boot.  Hats off to the Chef!

F5Vs7EJ3TiH1doOXzHXQuA.text: Great food, atmosphere, and friendly staff :) Go to's are smoked pineapple guacamole and jerk chicken with collard greens!! Yum!

ZBYsOmevLUn_294OYa_c8A.text: What a find! Delicious Island cuisine and a rum menu! Mahi Mahi tacos and Steak tacos rival Tako for developed flavors and so much more accessible.

qtrykVdx3ENjTCDGahsY6w.text: Absolutely amazing. We came here before seeing a show downtown without knowing too much besides reading other reviews on Yelp, and I have to say we were totally amazed. From the starter of the ceviche sampler to the tres leches dessert, there wasn't a single thing bad about the food. I had the fried fish of the day (red snapper) and I've never had a better piece of fried fish. The portion was extremely generous, and the coating was light yet full of flavor. The husband had the grouper, which we both agree wasn't quite as good as mine, but still wonderful. Bar service was quick which was good, and our waitress was very knowledgeable and efficient. We've been to several countries in the Caribbean, and we can honestly say this is as authentic as you can get in Pittsburgh. We will definitely be back!

Ma9oFctW5sVjchT_sG9iew.text: This is essentially and fantastically Pittsburgh's version of The Rum House in New Orleans. I am so happy that Pirata exists. I am in love.

BtJWu_rQ1LZoKNxuRs0NrA.text: Cool vibe. Overall good experience but the ingredients in the cocktails are very general.  I ordered a "cucumber margarita with fresh herbs" and I got a kale smoothie with tequila.  Nothing resembling a margarita. I will ask what the specific ingredients are next time.

UoggcmVr-Xn4ilF2F3r2Jw.text: Excellent food! If you get the tacos I recommend getting a side as well because although delicious they are not very large.

_JdeqbFsbwKbRuy_88FGbQ.text: Visited for the first time tonight, the day after Christmas. Marisole our server was great.  The cocktails  were very tasty and so was the food. We started out with chorizo sliders and octopus escabeche and the adobo wings. All great. We had the curried goat roti served like a taco and a Cubano sandwich. I think my favorite were the empanadas served with a tasty pepper salsa. The tres leche for dessert had a homemade marshmallow topping that was the best I've ever had. The coffee was very flavorful but not too strong.   The atmosphere was hip but comfortable. We will definitely be back.

mr27uVCSbq7IivdKDd2Hlw.text: This new addition to the market square is a haven of great food,  amazing rum and professional service

r1oilW73d01yvXcJeu4fpA.text: Huuuge , great service, great cocktails , great food , classy bar for a moving Pittsburgh.

H8m5TJpVpLx3aVFg8QJUKA.text: We met a couple of friends on a Friday night to try Pirata, as we love Cuban and other Caribbean food, and honestly there just isn't much of that in Pittsburgh.  They do take reservations, though I had a difficult time on their reservation app (I called and they were happy to put a reservation in for me).  The service was friendly and attentive, and the atmosphere captures the Caribbean theme while still somehow being classy.  My only complaint was that when they brought the food, they said the wrong name for the dish, and when we said we didn't order that, are they sure it wasn't the croquettes, both food runners looked mortified that they had no clue whether or not they were saying the right names to match the proper dishes.  It's a small menu, so there's not much reason for not being aware of the dishes you put out, but it's a new restaurant and it got sorted out, so I can excuse that.   First, it's a rum bar, and the cocktails are amazing.  I'm a bourbon/whiskey drinker myself, and typically find rum drinks to rely too much on sweetness, but they balanced the rum perfectly in these cocktails.  I would warn, however, that they are strong.  I can usually drink Manhattans and Old-fashioneds all night, but after two of the cocktails here, I was out.  The food was really good.  It wasn't the best I've ever had in my travels in terms of Cuban food, but I want to be relative here.  It's a lot easier to find a great place in NYC when you have a slew to choose from.  For Pittsburgh, this was more than enough to satisfy my craving.  The shrimp and polenta was creamy flavorful without being spicy, and it was a substantial portion size for the price.  The ropa vieja, a favorite of ours, was also a hit at the table.  The croquettes weren't that appealing to me (they just taste like "fried" to me, if that makes sense), and the cuban sandwich bite appetizers were good, but simple and small for the hefty price tag.  These critiques aside, all four of us left the restaurant with a positive impression, and all of us are eager to go back.

zdMxNhJ8KU_IBIZ_mAxfOQ.text: So I have never written one of these but I felt compelled tonight. I came here a month to the day the first time and I was amazed!  The place had only been open for a couple weeks and everything we ordered was perfect.  I am from south Florida and have had a very hard time finding good Latin/Caribbean cuisine. This place was on point and the flan was the best I had ever had. Today I found out that there is a new chef and a new menu.  Not impressed.  First the waitress told us that there was no bourbon or whiskey sold here (wrong). Then I found out that the amazing chips were no longer on the menu!  Nothing tastes the same, poor presentation and my Cuban sandwich was cut into strips!   The flan was atrocious.  Last month it was a thing of beauty and was almost like eating a creme brulee . Very sad, I was hoping this could have been a great go to place but unfortunately probably won't be. Get that chef back!

Hiuc4VLtjs5HEsIofwf16A.text: Went on a Saturday night ...service was extremely slow...got orders wrong.... Disappointing experience

lZea8tHzaMaukczcoDFAIw.text: So far, so good. A very clean and professionally-managed place. The staff serve you immediately and courteously.

me7BWxwbgchHgt8Uf_11AA.text: Had dinner here with my family while I was visiting Pgh for Thanksgiving. The menu and reviews looked good on-line so we made a reservation. We had to change the time and number of guests...very polite and courteous staff. My 86 yr old mother thought the music was too loud so they graciously moved us to the room in the back which was quiet. The margarita I ordered was tasty while interesting , one of the best I have ever tasted. We all loved our dinners...delicious with generous proportions. I highly recommend Pirata and agree with previous review which mentioned tasty cocktails and large portions. Our waitress could not have been more attentive.

fWkjNoYM5QbuP9tkQPgZvg.text: Everything about this place is great. Went there with my girlfriend and we had a great time. You walk in the and the ambiance and decor are all very nicely done. The bar area is very nicely set up. Got there and everyone from the hostess to the server were super nice. Ordered a few things: Patatas Bravas, tostones, a chicken and beef empanada and we both got the churassco tacos. The patatas braves were tasty and had a little buffalo taste to them, the empanadas had a thin tapa and the meat and chicken were both delicious. The tostones were also great, with a good amount of salt. My girlfriend really liked the aioli sauce that came with the tostones and empanadas. The tacos were delicious as well, the way they pickle their vegetables was awesome. We got all this for quite a reasonable price as well, about $20 each. Definitely recommend to go try it.

Gm_FVr1QqF2CPI24nPAJTA.text: The food here is awesome! The service was not so great. After being greeted by 3 different servers who ALL explained the menu to us (that was a little much) we waited 25 min for our actual server to take our order. Our entrees and app all came at the same time and we got a heirloom tomato and avocado salad (which was delicious) halfway through our meal. We also waited a while for the server to get our checks back to us. Not even a busy night. Couple other tables, but not crowded at all. Maybe it was an off night, idk. Ok, Let me get to the food, it was great! We loved everything! Pineapple guacamole was sooooo good! I had the pernil asado tacos, wonderful. My friends had the skirt steak with beans and rice and the fish fry, respectively. They both loved their dishes as well. Over all we really liked this place. Even the decor was very nice and attention was paid to details. I would have given a five star review was it not for the service. Hopefully they will fix that one important detail.

1VAP9IKna3mSoByC4cZJ5A.text: Pirata will be closing on December 27th.. I am so sad. This is my favorite restaurant.  A new restaurant will be at that location.  Thank you Pirata..for all the great food and memories!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. wings are back!!
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

CJFifGffu91oYISnMt9fXA.text: I was really impressed with the drinks and apps here. We had the croquettes and the pineapple guacamole with plantain chips. Both were unique and delicious. The drinks score big points on presentation, taste and alcohol content. I ordered a hibiscus cocktail with pineapple juice and pisco (Peruvian brandy), and it was fabulous! My table decided it was everyone's favorite drink, and all cocktails can be ordered by the pitcher. Their mojito is made with champagne instead of club soda/sparkling water. It was also delicious. I want to come back for happy hour because the drinks and apps are the highlight here. Our server told us the GM is a botanist, and she loves creating new, interesting cocktails.   For my main dish, I went with the traditional jerk chicken tacos and the leek empanadas. The tacos lacked some flavor and were on the bland side, but I noticed friends at our table struggling with the spice of their flank steak tacos, downing their drinks and watering from their eyes and noses in discomfort, so given that scenario, I probably made a better choice. The empanada was soft, yet crispy and packed with flavor.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

rI8ps3RnD8Prg9Lf2B_-8Q.text: My boyfriend and I went to Pirata for dinner on a Saturday night. We made a reservation for 9 PM but honestly we didn't need to because there a few empty tables and seating at the bar.  For drinks, we had a Bruja ($12) and a Jenny's Tea Cup (~$14). Drinks were decorated very nicely with flowers and skull cups, etc. The Bruja was my favorite - much better than Jenny's Tea Cup.  We ordered the Coconut Shrimp ($14) as an appetizer. Its kind of pricey for an appetizer but I do highly recommend. The appetizer includes 4 large shrimp served on top of a mango chutney and topped with green curry sauce. I could do without the green curry sauce but that mango chutney was delicious!  For dinner, we ordered the Fried Fish Sandwich (~$16) and Jerk Chicken ($24). I repeat $24 for jerk chicken and it was not worth it. The jerk chicken just was not jerk-y in any way. It was prepared fried and then baked so it was crispy but did not have much flavor. The Fried Fish sandwich on the other hand was wonderful. The fish was Red Snapper and it tasted so fresh and well prepared. The sandwich also included radish and papaya salad which provided great flavor. I substituted the side of fried for Bahamian Mac & Cheese which was fine. It was spicy but nothing to write home about.  Overall, I enjoyed my meal. Pirata is a nice restaurant for a Caribbean dinner, however it is on the pricier side.

Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fried fish (Red Snapper) sandwich and Bahamian mac and cheese
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Menu as of 3/2018

x7NGwi2JWMvIZEPQmt6R0Q.text: Went here for our anniversary lunch yesterday. I absolutely loved the look and feel of the restaurant. The one thing I noticed was it was super quiet. The tv's weren't on, music wasn't playing, and the place was fairly empty. I'm not sure if it's usually that quiet but it wasn't necessarily a bad thing.  We started off with the pineapple guacamole. OMG so good. The chips were really different. They don't provide a lot of chips so we ended up putting the rest of the guacamole on our sandwiches. I ordered the fish of the day sandwich and my hubby had the sandwich with jerk chicken and a veggie empanada. Both come with fries but I asked to substitute a side salad. The salad was mouth watering. Nothing that I had expected. Literally the BEST side salad in my life. It had different colored tomatoes, goat cheese, chickpeas just to name a few things in it. I would love that as my entree.  Their drink menu was quite extensive and went with the pirate theme. Im not a liquor drinker but loved that there were so many choices.  Pirata is pricier so I wouldn't come here everyday but would definitely come back on a special occasion.  Service was great and it didn't take long to get our food.

a2eETA4O8YHDOd8sUd7jXQ.text: Wish I would've came here sooner. This is the best Caribbean food in town hands down. Everything was so good and I got the feeling of authentic Caribbean cuisine.   How could I forget to mention the rum bar! At least one hundred different rums to choose from all over the world! I chose a seven year rum from Mexico on the rocks that was smoother than silk. Not to mention a variety of beers, wines and other spirits on the menu.  I highly suggest the empanadas and pineapple guacamole, a combination that can't be duplicated. I think I've said enough, come here and decide for yourself. I guarantee you won't be disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

rx6ccpSRDWzvvEPls995Dg.text: Went to Pirata on a whim with a couple of friends. Our dinner plans changed, so we turned to Yelp, which suggested Pirata. Boy, am I glad we went! This is such a cool little place with a neat concept. How many Caribbean style restaurants do we have in Pittsburgh? Definitely something unique and different to try. One friend ordered the pineapple guacamole as an appetizer and it was served with plantain chips. It was very fresh and tasty, and I feel like plantain chips are a healthier alternative to corn chips! Myself and another friend both ordered the skirt steak tacos and they were delicious! You get 2 tacos per order. Highly recommend! We also split a side of fries. It was a huge order! One order is plenty for the whole table to share. My only regret Is that I wish one of us would have ordered a different kind of taco so we could swap one and try one of each! If you're going in a group, I would suggest everyone order something different and then do some trading! They have 2 different hot sauces. One is pineapple something and the other is mango something. They look and sound fruity, but they were HOT. like really hot. And I love hot hot sauce! A sprinkle is all you need... Lastly, my fourth friend ordered the salmon salad that was on special and it looked incredible! I've never seen a more colorful salad! The salmon itself was a tad bland, but the house dressing made up for it! She also ordered a side of Mac n cheese and let me have a bite. I was a fan!  Pirata also had a very extensive and impressive run list. I, myself am a rum drinker, but I opted out of getting a cocktail because I was driving.  I can say that I will definitely be back to Pirata to try other things on the menu and test out some of their rum cocktails!

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Skirt steak tacos
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

t8MgBDCq7KCRSvjjm1iQuQ.text: Unfortunately Pirata was a miss for me. I was excited to try Pirata after checking out their menu and seeing the food pictures on Yelp.  My husband and I split the fish sandwich and turkey/cream cheese panini.  The fish sandwich was the better of the two. It was a good sandwich but nothing special.  The turkey panini sounded really good on the menu but I did not like it at all. It was actually kind of gross. There was way too much turkey and not enough of the other flavors. They have a great concept with the turkey sandwich but a bad execution of it.  Also, the music, too loud! I get they wanna have a bar feel, loud music, drinks, etc., but if you are also a sit down restaurant there needs to be a happy medium. I don't feel like yelling to have a conversation with the person sitting across the table from me. The music selection was good, just turn it down a little, please.  I honestly don't think I'll be back to Pirata in the future.

EkECPwmnz7qVtekNqyqg8A.text: Came on Tuesday afternoon and the place was empty, and I absolutely do not understand why. This restaurant was absolutely phenomenal.  Atmosphere A+ -- perfect place to bring a date or just have a small outing with friends. Beautiful lighting and comfortable seating. Bar is stationed in the center of the restaurant and has a great variety of drinks.  Service A+ -- very friends waitress. Always came by to fill up waters or check on how we were doing. And even if she didn't always pass by directly in front of us, she was very attentive and always knew when we needed anything.  Food A+ -- wow wow wow. First of all, the flavors!! The spice and textures... I honestly cannot stop raving about this place. I got the SMOKED JACKFRUIT vegan taco ($13) and beef empanadas ($4). and because I'm a spice lover, I paired them with both of the original hot sauces they had at the table (my favorite was the mango habanero). Smoked jackfruit taco was especially unique. Looks like meat, but has the smooth and silky texture of jackfruit.  Taco skin was also made from red beets I believe.  Highly recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Smoked jackfruit taco and beef empanadas

8IK1md2Q0rECg-uuZchaKA.text: Delish. Jerk chicken entree with collards. You'd swear the collards were made with lard, they're so rich... Nope, totally vegan, made with coconut fat. The chef dials back the spice so it's slightly Americanized jerk but you can heat it with the house made mango habanero sauce. They also have a milder, vinegar based red pepper sauce that it super tasty as well. I bought a bottle of each to take home and put on eggs, fish tacos, etc.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Jerk chicken entree, collards, beans and rice. House made mango habanero and red pepper sauces.

Q9SDG65qdfDqCoxpnl7o7Q.text: I was able to find seating as soon as I walked in on a Tuesday night at 6:30 pm. The waitress was kind in granting me happy hour prices although I admittedly was a tad late to the party. I ordered a margarita and the guacamole trio. The margarita was just a classic marg- nothing fancy but tasted great. The guacamole, on the other hand, was short of impressive. Contrary to the multiple reviews posted here about the guac, I would not spend $12 on 3 samples of their three flavors ($16 when not on happy hour) the flavor was lackluster and my bias probably comes out of being from the west coast; I need more flavor, onions, salt, cilantro etc, something! to wow me. I would, however, tell my people to come if they're in the area for the ambience, HH drinks, and music...spend your $12 in a different way! Last, but most important for my frequent bathroom users: bathroom is clean, multiple stalls and has a trendy mirror Hallway which leads to your grand entrance into the toilet... definitely here for it.

Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Happy hour 4:30-6:30 m-f

wvYAiNtLUCdn0N8rhySXLg.text: Stopped in a little after 5 on a Friday night, and were seated pretty much immediately. Our server was incredibly friendly and happy to answer all of our numerous questions.  To drink we ordered the Jenny's Tea Cup, and Message in a Bottle, both rum based. The first is definitely more of a fruity drink (quite good), and the second mostly tastes like ginger soda with some rum (which honestly is great to me). It was cool in that it came with the dark rum in a little bottle separate to pour into the drink yourself (the message in the bottle). The dark rum lent the drink almost a maple-y aftertaste. Yum.  For main dishes we ordered the smoked jackfruit (vegetarian) tacos, which I would highly recommend- almost the texture of meat exactly! And the arroz con pollo, of which I tried the rice and it was really tasty. I felt that both dishes were a bit overpriced though, at $14 for two small tacos, and $20 something for the arroz con pollo.  They were out of the bread pudding for dessert (insert major disappointment) so we decided to try the tres leches. It was *okay* but I've had much, much better. The milk wasn't sweet enough, and the cake hadn't soaked through the whole way. The topping was too thick and didn't have much flavor.  3.5 overall because the jackfruit tacos were interesting, the rice was really good, and the service was friendly.

Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Smoked jackfruit tacos

fSmrNl2RnzTVdP5jUo3ylw.text: Cool walls! They really added something to the experience.   I wasn't too hungry, so I decided to go for a salad and the watermelon and honey salad caught my eye. It was a very vibrant salad: kale, picked watermelon rind (tasted like candy!), goat cheese, chickpeas, and honey. For some reason I expected there to be less honey drizzled on. I would've preferred less. Still a good salad though, and it came in a pretty large portion. I also ordered an empanada ($4 each). You can't come here without ordering one! I chose the Jamaican beef patty empanada and it was so tasty. (Why did I order just one?! If I come back, I totally would just order a bunch of empanadas and call it a meal.)  For drinks, I had originally ordered the Antigua Tea, which was good, but after having a sip of my friend's Jenny's Teacup and after she had a sip of my Antigua Tea, we decided to switch drinks because we liked the other person's drink better.   Good service, but I noticed that our table was not wiped before we were seated.   Taste | 4 Atmosphere | 4 Presentation | 4 Service | 4 OVERALL | 4

EGUCnfnAQpyYAGqRHiKouA.text: This place has a Rum Bible to go with their main menu. What else do you need to know?  Pirata, an Latin American rum bar, is officially one of my favorite places downtown. I had ordered empanadas to-go for lunch a while ago, but after eating here for real with my family last week it'll be hard to settle for takeout again. The decor alone sucks you in as it definitely wants to take you away from city life temporarily. There are murals of the seashore and ocean-themed colors everywhere you look. It's very bright and relaxing, if not beach-side levels of cheesy, and I love it.  And no seashore experience is complete until you've had some rum, right? Pirata's website boasts that they offer over 200 varieties of rum. There are wine and beer options as well, but I can guarantee I'll never order them here - not when the best rum cocktails I've come across are served here by very nice and prompt servers and bartenders.  On top of knowing their rum, this place's food is legit. My family and I ordered and shared their Cubano sandwich, skirt steak tacos, and and pollo frito sandwich. The pollo frito was mine - a buttermilk and jerk brined chicken sandwich with jerk BBQ, slaw, and pickles, all served with a giant side of of fries. This may be the greatest fried chicken sandwich I've eaten to date - the chicken was literally melt-in-my-mouth good, and the flavor profile that came with its toppings was just delightful. As far as I was concerned, my meal was the best thing at our table.  Not that the other entrees were bad. The Cubano was pretty good, although it's more of a Cuban panini than a proper Cuban sandwich. If they ever decide to use proper Cuban bread I'd order a sandwich for myself instantly, because the toppings themselves were quite tasty and well prepped. The steak tacos were downright delicious, and in addition to featuring tender and fresh ingredients they were one of the spicier items my table ordered. The other contender for most spicy dish was the mac and cheese, which my family ordered to share. This is very good thick and creamy mac and cheese, but be aware of what you're getting into when you order it - otherwise your tastebuds are in for a big surprise!  The only downside of the meal for us was that the fries the sandwiches came with were easily the saltiest things I've eaten in recent memory. We're talking "saltier than fast food fries" salty; no one wanted to eat more than a couple handfuls of them during dinner (they actually got better after being reheated at home). I would definitely not complain if the kitchen backed off on the salt and I'll likely avoid ordering meals that come with the fries in the future (although hopefully Pirata will let me substitute a different side? We'll see!).  Like I said, this place is now one of my favorite places downtown - if I could give them a 4.5 I would, as they are just a few menu tweaks away from being perfect. I expect that I'll be back again soon, as the main courses, desserts, and drinks alike are all calling my name. Definitely come in soon, and drink up me hearties!

j4N7CxppQWsSzlHMjQA5Qg.text: I had no clue this place existed! I went with some friends one night on a whim and am glad I did! I didn't love the idea of a Caribbean restaurant because I'm just not a huge fan of that type of food. I typically would not have picked this place but I was very impressed and eager to try something new! I got the salmon salad that was on special that night...omg amazing! One of the best salads I've had. The piece of salmon was a decent size but the flavor was nothing special. The rest of the salad and dressing made up for it! I hope next time I go back that salad is on special again. I also got the Mac n cheese. I had to try it. It's not your traditional Mac n cheese, it had a kick to it but I liked it. My friends got the steak tacos and enjoyed them. They also seemed like a good size, 2 tacos per order. If you're a rum drinker then you must go! They offer a very extensive rum list. I recommend if you're looking to try something new!

I7euPbsTrY808fC1hwiLGw.text: We walked into Pirata and it was surprisingly slow for a Saturday night in Market Square. We were immediately greeted- and the service was excellent throughout the entire meal. We had pineapple guacamole with plantain chips to start. It was very tasty! The chips tasted maybe a little stale to me, but maybe that's just the texture of them. It wasn't awful. We each had tacos as our meal. I had the fish tacos, hubby had steak. Both were excellent and surprisingly spicy- served with some interesting homemade salsas to add some extra flavor. Quite yummy. We also each had a drink- a mojito and a margarita- they were good as well. The best parts of this place are the decor, service and wonderfully flavorful food. It's quite an experience if you take the time to look around. Murals, private rooms you can peek in, bathrooms are cool, too! One star missing because the cost is a little high for what you are getting. Drink prices were high, too. But hey, it's a nice night out. Would definitely come back!

FmpHTfl-wZLgX-R9-vRhyw.text: The beef empanadas were fantastic, so good!! Extremely knowledgeable about the rum. Let us try a few samples and taught us so much!! Great food, awesome spot. Really cool experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

2uXyxIwrXcld5UFvNCK3mQ.text: I struggled between 3 and 4 stars for here.  I would say a solid 3.5 stars.   We went with a large group and were put into their back room, which I imagine is available as an event space.  There were interesting paintings on the walls, but we couldn't tell what one of them was.  Potentially a Kracken? The chairs and table are large, which gives you a lot of room to spread out while you're eating.  I ordered the jerk chicken tacos and they were very good, but the taco shell could barely contain them, and they were served on a cutting-board-esque platter without edges.  I ended up losing a decent amount of my dish to the table.  Also, there was no warning how spicey my dish was going to be.  This was fine for me, but one of my friends ordered the same thing and had to have a new dish made for her since she doesn't like spice.  My husband ordered the veggie curry and really liked his dish a lot.  He now wants to eat more vegetarian options at home.   I think the food was good, but the tacos were a little bit pricey.

Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Jerk chicken tacos

pHMsPqQDW61ljO27ZpY0sQ.text: Came in for drinks and appetizers...the staff was awesome and the drinks and empanadas were great!! The bartender even took some time to teach us about all the different varieties of rum! It is a little expensive but definitely worth checking out especially if you love rum!!

fH_AGiSrGOyR_hMD8bZKGg.text: My wife and I went to Pirata for dinner a few days after Christmas for a date night out. We decided to sit at the bar and were greeted by Randolf, who ended up taking care of us for the next several hours. Every cocktail we ordered was based off of bartenders recommendations after asking about what we liked. He was spot on each time with the next drink being better then the previous. I highly suggest the Zombie flight and the Bruja cocktail (skull glass in the pictures).   For food, the smoked pineapple guacamole is absolutely incredible. After a surprising recommendation for the coconut shrimp we gave them a shot. Coconut shrimp, in my opinion tend to be the same everywhere. Over cooked with some random sugary concoction for a dip. Not at Pirata though.  There were 4 massive shrimp, fried perfectly so that the shrimp were still tender served with a spicy but slightly sweet chutney and curry sauces. They were amazing. Our entrees were the jerk chicken and the fish fry (Cobia this occasion), both excellent as well.  It was 5 degrees outside but the rum was flowing keeping us nice and warm inside all night. My wife and I actually closed up the bar that evening and were the last customers out the door. Time flies when you're having rum! Can't wait to go back.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

CA3dt_z4RPQZN862vXhD5Q.text: Well my Yelp friends, Yelp led me to Pirata and it didn't disappoint! The food had good flavor and it is unique to what else you can find downtown. Arriving at 11:45 for a Friday lunch was great timing as only a few other tables had been taken at that point. The staff was incredibly friendly and were ready to answer questions and make suggestions.  There were three of us, and we decided to try the Cuban Sandwich Bites (app), each had an Empanada, and then we shared the Mac & Cheese and the sweet plantains. Hands down, the Empanadas took the prize. These things were delicious, meaty, pockets of YUM! Each one is $3 and there are two beef flavors and one chicken. The man who delivered the food offered hot sauce, and yes! I added that to the salsa that comes with it for a great tasting, spicy treat.   I knew from another review that the mac & cheese had a nutmeg flavor to it. It was good, but as the three of us discussed, we think we'd probably want to focus on other things before trying it again. Both people I dined with liked the cuban bites quite a bit - but we were all surprised that they came out looking more like egg rolls (check out my picture to see) but were still very good! I'm not a big honey mustard fan, but it didn't deter me from trying, and I'd try them again.  Although we all agreed we were full from the dishes the waitress mentioned the bread pudding for dessert, and I just couldn't pass it up. Bananas, walnuts... sounded like magic. Unfortunately this was our least favorite part. While the dish and the outer ring of the dessert was "scalding hot" as the waitress warned us - the center of the dessert was very cold. Some of the crust had a burnt taste to it as well, so while I"m hoping it was a fluke, I don't think I'd spend the money again to find out. As I mentioned, the service was very friendly but at times felt slow, so rushed lunchers may want to wait until you have some buffer time just in case it is busy.

photos.caption: Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bread pudding for dessert!
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The Cuban sandwich bites.
Photo of Pirata - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pollo empanada. The hot sauce is great!

6XJS4LtBezaIDA9zY4KKFg.text: Stopped here before a wedding reception to grab drinks and were both pleasantly surprised. We sat at the bar and the ambiance was nice... Cozy chairs with red velvet seats and a bright picture of the sea painted on the side wall. They have a back room that also holds about 30. My husband had a red stripe and I sipped on a few glasses of wine, which were both reasonably priced. We decided to try a beef patty as well. The exterior of the patty was flaky, and although the meat inside was not the juiciest ever, it was not dry either; it was an average patty, according to my Jamaican husband. It came with a delicious red sauce for dipping, which was mild and flavor. This particular sauce was not traditional to Jamaican culture, but it did pair well with the beef patty. The waitstaff was extremely pleasant and knowledgeable of menu items. Bathrooms were well-kept. The only downfall noted is there is no happy hour- would have loved to come back for drinks but maybe they will change that in the future.. Hooks under the bar do not exist for purses ladies, but that's a minor detail. We can't wait to try the jerk chicken during our next visit!
